---
title: Git and GitHub Installation & Setup
---

::: {.unit-overview}
# Overview
Before you can track changes you need Git on your computer and a few
global settings that stamp each commit with your identity.
:::

::: {.unit-goals}
# Goals
* Install the latest stable Git on Windows, macOS, or Linux  
* Configure your username, email, and default branch name  
* Generate an SSH key and add it to GitHub  
* Verify connectivity with `git ls-remote`
:::



::: {.unit-resources}
# Further resources

* **Git Downloads** – <https://git-scm.com/downloads>  
* **Generating SSH Keys** – <https://docs.github.com/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh>  
* **Git Credential Storage** – <https://git-scm.com/docs/gitcredentials>
:::

::: {.unit-exercise}
# Practice

1. Install Git and confirm `git --version` ≥ 2.40.  
2. Set your global username and email.  
3. Generate an SSH key and add it to your GitHub account.  
4. Clone `git@github.com:octocat/Hello-World.git` to verify SSH access.  
5. Change the default editor (`git config --global core.editor "nano"` or similar).
:::
